header.title: MEZLIM Volume VI. Issue No. 4: Practical Magick for Today (Samhain 1995) - The Bardic Tradition
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Magick, Paganism, NeoPaganism

central_thesis: MEZLIM is dedicated to exploring and supporting growth-oriented magickal movements during the transition into a 'new aeon' by presenting information, views, images, and ideas that celebrate the spirituality of the Living Earth. This issue specifically focuses on 'The Bardic Tradition' as a unifying element and creative essence within both historical and modern magickal contexts, emphasizing practical applications of ancient wisdom for contemporary practitioners.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bard of the festival by Louis Martinie
structure_content.summary: This article discusses the evolving role of the Bard in the magickal community, particularly at festivals. It highlights the Bard's traditional function as a unifier through language and storytelling, and proposes the 'Festival Drummer' as the modern equivalent, capable of facilitating communication in diverse spiritual environments through three distinct drumming styles: Community, Specific, and Trance Drumming.

structure_content.chapter_title: Where are the bards? by Jaq D. Hawkins
structure_content.summary: This piece explores the historical role of Bards as news carriers and social commentators, noting how technology has diminished this function in the modern Western world. It recognizes the continuation of the Bardic tradition in re-enactment societies, Druidic orders, and within small communities as a 'creative essence' that expresses lessons through artistic creation and ritual.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Bard, yesterday and today by Rick Allen
structure_content.summary: The author examines the Bard's enduring role from ancient Celtic traditions, where they preserved pagan lore and influenced legends like Arthurian tales, to modern music forms. It argues that contemporary folk, country, and even rap music continue the Bardic tradition of storytelling, emphasizing music's power to influence and the responsibility of the musician.

structure_content.chapter_title: Q: Are we not men? A: We are bards! by Massimo Mantovani
structure_content.summary: This article posits that modern magickal practitioners, especially musicians and artists, are the Bards of the new aeon. It argues that through art and music, they create and communicate the burgeoning 'Culture' of Paganism, Wicca, and Magick, drawing inspiration from their magical paths and influencing the world's perception of these lifestyles.

structure_content.chapter_title: The power of word by KIA
structure_content.summary: This piece analyzes 'Word' as a potent magickal tool, not merely communication. Drawing parallels to Egyptian hieroglyphs and the god Tehuti, it asserts that words create reality and influence body chemistry. It emphasizes conscious intent, truth, and accountability in speech for effective Will-based magick, warning against unconscious use or 'cliches'.

structure_content.chapter_title: The magic of masks by Patricia Telesco
structure_content.summary: This article delves into the symbolic and practical uses of masks across cultures and throughout history, from ancient rituals to modern psychological applications. Masks are presented as tools for exploring the imagination, embodying divine or animal spirits, transforming identity, and ritually disposing of negative characteristics, thereby facilitating self-discovery and magical change.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Vampire in me by Paul Joseph Rovelli
structure_content.summary: From a Thelemic perspective, this article discusses the 'Vampire' as an internal entity representing unconscious habits and desires that 'suck' spiritual energy and hinder self-mastery. It describes the struggle against this inner adversary as essential for spiritual progress, requiring vigilance, self-awareness, and turning away from self-destructive tendencies.

structure_content.chapter_title: The ethics of Thelema by Robert S. Pendell
structure_content.summary: This article provides a technical exegesis of Aleister Crowley's 'Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law,' clarifying 'True Will' as the divine consciousness within, distinct from egoic whims. It integrates Thelemic principles with concepts of divine love and individual purpose, arguing for a non-interfering, egalitarian ethical framework where each individual's True Will aligns with universal harmony.

structure_content.chapter_title: The cult of the divine artist by Andrew D. Chumbley
structure_content.summary: This piece explores the Zos Kia Cultus, its origins with Austin Osman Spare, and its connection to the Sabbatic Mysteries and Typhonian tradition. It defines the 'Divine Artist' as one who manifests the 'Magical Current' through imaginal interaction and the 'Living Flesh,' emphasizing creativity as a pathway to gnosis and the realization of inherent dream.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Heretic's Corner: Kabbalistic Blockbusting by Dr. Richard Kaczynski
structure_content.summary: This article critiques conventional views of the Kabbalistic Tree of Life, advocating for breaking self-imposed intellectual limits. It introduces the 'Cube of Space' as a three-dimensional and four-dimensional (hypercube) projection derived from the Sepher Yetzirah, offering a more dynamic understanding of Kabbalistic paths and sephiroth beyond flat diagrams.

structure_content.chapter_title: Review: Women of The Golden Dawn by Donald Michael Kraig
structure_content.summary: This is a critical review of Mary Greer's book, assessing its examination of women's roles in the Golden Dawn. Kraig highlights strengths in historical information but critiques the book's 'women-as-victims' feminist framing, astrological interpretations, and specific historical claims (e.g., Karezza, King's views on skrying, Waite's Tarot designs), emphasizing the need for technical accuracy in occult studies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Neophyte's Niche: The Next Step by Donna Stanford-Blake
structure_content.summary: This personal reflection likens spiritual growth to navigating a roller coaster or crossroads, emphasizing the inevitability of fear and challenges. It advises practitioners to confront fears, practice self-reflection through journaling and meditation, and cultivate focus and discipline to progress on their magickal path, acknowledging that the process is unique and continuous.

key_concepts.definition: Derived from the Aramaic version of the Hebrew word 'Mazel', it literally means 'the influence of the divine,' or 'the sparks emanating from Kether,' the Crown of the Tree of Life. It signifies the divine presence across diverse spiritual paths.

A modern evolution of the Bard's role, particularly in festival settings, responsible for facilitating communication and community through drumming. Expected to master Community, Specific, and Trance drumming styles.

A style of drumming that expresses and invokes the spirit of the entire festival community. It is typically loud, medium to fast, with a strong underlying 4/4 beat that allows for diverse individual rhythmic expressions, commonly heard when the fire is first ignited.

A drumming style that utilizes particular rhythms associated with one or more esoteric traditions to invoke or evoke specific Deities. It allows drummers to learn and share rhythms unique to various magickal paths.

A late-night/early-morning drumming style characterized by slow tempo and simple rhythmic phrases, repeated over and over to induce a trance state. It is associated with intense magickal work and contacting the Sacred.

Beyond mere communication, words are magickal tools that create reality. Conscious and truthful use of words, akin to the Egyptian god Tehuti's role in creating hieroglyphs, is integral to Will-based magick, influencing both internal and external planes.

Objects used in ritual and daily life for symbolic transformation. They allow exploration of imagination, embodiment of divine or animal spirits, and ritualistic engagement with aspects of self (e.g., destroying bad habits, inspiring healing). Masks facilitate self-discovery and magical change by altering perception and persona.

In Thelemic philosophy, the 'Vampire' is an internal 'energy sucker' or 'spiritual tape-worm' representing unconscious habits and desires that impede spiritual progress and self-mastery. The fight against the Vampire is the ongoing process of vigilance and overcoming self-deceit.

The essential divine purpose of an individual, distinct from egoic whims or desires. It is the 'spark of God that lives within us,' leading to actions aligned with divine love and bringing light, life, love, and liberty. Discovering and accomplishing True Will is the core of Thelemic practice.

A specialized system of sorcery associated with Austin Osman Spare, rooted in the Sabbatic Mysteries and Typhonian tradition. It describes how the 'Divine Artist' manifests the 'Magical Current' through imaginal interaction and the 'Living Flesh,' allowing for the expression of primordial dreams and gnosis.

A three-dimensional (and four-dimensional hypercube) geometric projection of the Sepher Yetzirah. It maps the Hebrew Mother Letters to the X, Y, Z axes, and other letters/sephiroth to its structure, offering a spatial understanding of Kabbalistic principles beyond two-dimensional diagrams.

A trance state induced by yogic breath-control during sexual intercourse, where participants withhold physical orgasm while allowing female orgasm. Discussed in the context of Golden Dawn studies, though its historical attribution to Thomas Lake Harris is critically examined.

practical_system.description: MEZLIM serves as a compendium of articles that collectively inform and inspire the practical application of diverse magickal systems. It emphasizes the integration of ancient traditions with modern approaches, focusing on personal empowerment, conscious creation of reality, and the development of inner awareness. The magazine encourages readers to explore various tools and techniques to facilitate spiritual growth and manifest their 'True Will' within their communities.
tools: Drums (for various styles of festival drumming).
Words, language, poetry, songs, and music (as tools for creation, influence, and communication in magick).
Masks, costumes, and symbolic tokens/jewelry (for ritual transformation and self-expression).
The Kabbalistic 'Cube of Space' (as a visualization aid for understanding the Tree of Life and Sepher Yetzirah).
Personal journals (for tracking spiritual progress, self-reflection, and clarifying intent).
Meditation (for gaining wisdom, inner guidance, and managing emotions).
rituals: Festival Drumming (Community, Specific, Trance) to foster community, invoke deities, and induce trance states.
Mask rituals for self-transformation, embodying spirits, ritual destruction of negative habits, and inspiring healing.
Thelemic practices focusing on discovering and enacting one's 'True Will' through conscious choice and alignment with divine love.
Zos Kia Cultus practices involving imaginal interaction and artistic expression to manifest the 'Magical Current.'
The 'Dumb Supper,' a folk custom involving silent, backward cooking to achieve specific, unstated purposes.
Kabbalistic meditations and visualizations using the 'Cube of Space' for a deeper, multi-dimensional understanding of the Sepher Yetzirah.
Personal practices of self-reflection, journaling, and meditation to confront fears and clarify one's spiritual path.

relevant_quotes.text: Just what does the word 'Mezlim' mean, anyway? It means, literally, 'the influence of the divine', or 'the sparks emanating from Kether', the Crown of the Tree of Life. It references the fact that the divine lives in many paths, with each path as unique as the individuals who walk it.

Here at MEZLIM, we subscribe to the premise that we are entering a new aeon - a new age - which is bringing and will continue to bring many changes in the way we see ourselves and the world around us. We are dedicated to presenting information, views, images and ideas concerned with our transition into this new world which we are creating. Our editorial policy is androgynous, egalitarian and eclectic, supporting all growth oriented, magickal movements; celebrating the spirituality of the Living Earth!
Hear the voice of the Bard! Who present, past, and future sees.
Ω e too the Muses made write verse.
Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law.
Every man and every woman is a star.
The Mask is used at those times when human experience is transforming—birth, death, initiation, seasons of the year, the basic cycle of life

The Bard lives on, but not in the form that once was. We still have our storytellers and minstrels within small communities, and this is how we see the Bard. Yet the Bard also lives on in the modern music and in each story we make up for a child.
The Bard is the creative essence within us that gives life to the lessons we learn and express through artistic creation.

critical_analysis.relevance: MEZLIM directly addresses contemporary relevance by framing its content within the context of a 'new aeon' and societal transition, offering practical magickal insights for modern practitioners. It actively supports diverse 'growth oriented, magickal movements,' making it a pertinent resource for individuals seeking to integrate esoteric philosophy into their lives and contribute to a developing 'Culture' of magick.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magick (including Chaos Magic, Qabalah, Hermeticism, Thelema, Wicca, and Paganism). It also caters to individuals interested in spiritual growth, self-transformation, and alternative religious and philosophical viewpoints, particularly those engaged in magickal communities and festivals.
